value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">To <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tlat" key="Latimer, Thomas">Latimer</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rhoo" key="Robin Hood">Robin Hood</rs> was a <add place="above">[illeg.]</add> thief. <del>He was</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He had walked in the shadow of death " till he was 30,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but then his eyes were opened, & he was through</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>the cloud</del> <del>of</del> superstition <del>that <del>still</del> obscured his</del> thought</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He <del>saw things as they were</del>, he saw through the old</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>popish</del> through the old Popish preachers, the old</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">pagan customs. He saw England still, at the moment</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in its reality. He was no antiquary. He did</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not dig in the garden for roman coins. When he</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">walked in the 
            <choice><sic>A of C</sic>
              <corr>Archbishop of Canterbury's</corr>
            </choice> garden, <del>a man</del> his man</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">came & said: <quote source="#" rend="inline">"Sir there is one that 
            <choice>
              <sic>wd.</sic>
              <corr>would</corr>
            </choice> speak</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">with you."</quote> <add place="above">Then</add> He shut his house, a <del>heart</del> He</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>he said</del> so <quote source="#" rend="inline">"the cry of the washerman is come up</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>up to <del>my ears</del> "mine ears" The poor Labourers,</l>
            <l>Gun makers, Powdermen, Bow makers, Arrow makers,</l>
            <l>Smiths, Carpenters, [Solderers?], & other crafts</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">cry out..."</quote> <add place="margin">111</add>  Then he [unpaid?]. <del>So</del> He laid</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aside his book.    He <del>found</del> waited on the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great man & found him still in bed. <quote source="#" rend="inline">They</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">the <del>prelates</del> <del>they hawke</del></quote> He found the prelates,</l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>They hawke, they hunt, they carde, they dice</l>
            <l>they patronise in the palaces with [gallows?]</l>
            <l>flatterers, with their dancing mummers, & with</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">their fresh companions...</quote> Standing up by the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the King himself he laid bare the state of England. In a voice that starts & stammers</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">repeating the word as in his hard</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[powder?] the [cake?], he [fight?] to the English</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[illeg.]</l>
<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">111</add>
